Description.val:
The F-22 Raptor provides air superiority to the Joint Force; access in the highly contested operational environment; as well as, homeland and cruise missile defense for the next 40+ years. The F-22 is the first operational multi-mission fighter aircraft that combines stealth, supercruise, maneuverability and integrated avionics to make it the world's most capable combat aircraft. The F-22 is currently in the post-production operations phase of it's acquisition lifecycle and therefore utilizes an acquisition strategy of balanced modernization and sustainment to maintain its asymmetric war fighting advantage. F-22 modernization and sustainment programs invest in upgrades to the air vehicle, engine, and training systems to improve F-22 weapons, communications, and Intelligence Surveillance Reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities. Funds may be used to resolve emerging safety of flight and diminishing manufacturing sources issues, accommodate technology insertion and fulfill FAA or other mandates necessary to ensure continued aircrew safety and mission effectiveness.

Funding for the exhibit contained in Program (PE) 0207138F.

In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Description.val: The TACLink-16 program accelerates fielding of key technologies previously aligned under the F-22 Tactical Mandates (TACMAN) program.  FY 2018 Advance Procurement for TACLink 16 procures long lead materials associated with the production and deployment of the TacLink 16 program.  The funds will procure specialized equipment to include benches, racks, trays, processors as well as titanium to support the group A installation of Polyalphaolefin (PAO) manifolds.  TackLink 16 installation is currently projected to begin in FY 2021 and will retrofit 142 aircraft.

Justification.val: Advance procurement prevents a 16-24 month delay to start kit production and deployment, with titanium being the longest lead item.  TAClink 16 is a new start.

Description.val:
Common Configuration upgraded the F-22 production aircraft to reduce fielded OFP configurations from six to three -- Block 20, Block 30 and Block 35.  Block 30 and 35 Raptors will be further upgraded with Increment 3.1 (complete in FY 2017) and 3.2 capabilities. 

Common configuration installation completed in FY 2017.

Milestone/Development Status

Development complete

Increment 3.1 hardware modifications enabled the F-22 to host Increment 3.1 capabilities including retargeting Joint Direct Attack Munitions (JDAM), carriage and delivery of the Small Diameter Bomb (SDB) on preplanned missions using the Joint Mission Planning System (JMPS), using Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Air-to-Ground radar mode to permit attack of emerging targets, and saving SAR imagery onto the Tactical Data Transfer System (TDTS) for post-mission analysis.

Increment 3.1 modernized the F-22 aircraft with Enhanced Central Integrated Processor (ECIP) cards, a new Map Inter-Face (MIF) board for the 4th generation APG-77VI radar, a modification to the GPS Inertial Navigation System (GINS), and a TDTS.

Kit installations were completed in FY 2017.

Milestone/Development Status

Development complete.

Reliability, Availability, and Maintainability Program (RAMP) provides solution identification and integration of modifications to improve reliability, availability and maintainability (RAM) for the F-22 fleet. The associated RAMP efforts (O&S funded) develop candidate initiatives, which are down-selected by air Combat Command, for implementation based on development maturity and impact on the F-22 life cycle costs. The RAMP program includes funding for retrofit installation touch labor, modifications to address corrosion, reduce maintenance hours, increase safety and provide urgent response requirements identified by the user to the F-22 fleet.  Urgent response requirements are quick demand requirements addressing safety or air superiority, ensuring the warfighter and the weapon system are operating as intended.  RAMP funds may be used to resolve emerging safety of flight and diminishing manufacturing sources issues, accommodate technology insertion and fulfill FAA or other mandates necessary to ensure continued aircrew safety and mission effectiveness. RAMP includes mission support costs for the F-22 program to include, but not be limited to travel, computer costs and contractor support.

The RAMP modifications program currently include individual RAMP projects, totaling over 9,600 kits, which retrofitted onto aircraft based on aircraft downtime opportunities. In FY 2019, RAMP kit procurement and installation will continue on projects such as; Configurable Rail Launchers (CRL) AIM-9X extension kits which enable AIM-9X employment; Low Observable (LO) Mighty Tough Boot which replaces less durable boot material and  leads to an estimated 3% increase in aircraft reliability; field level replacement of CNI AAI Cables (current cable failing at 10% of 8,000 hour life - new cable eliminates any direct maintenance on cable assembly); FIBER Infrastructure which maximizes connectivity and preserves 10 maintenance days of aircraft availability per tail number; and the Aft Boom Surface which replaces damage to the leading flap surface area that if not corrected will ground the fleet at 2,100 hours. Every RAMP retrofit kit, to include those not listed, has a component level improvement metric and  contributes to the overall availability and reliability improvement of the F-22. 

Kit installations are completed at either the depot or by a contractor field team depending on the complexity of the installation effort and scheduled aircraft downtime opportunities. Quantities are based on an assumed maturity of the solution identification and are subject to change over time. The average cost per kit varies based on planned retrofit kits in a given year and the complexity of the materials and labor required to integrate and install on the fleet. 



This program was formerly the Reliability, Availability and Maintainability Maturations Program (RAMMP).

Milestone/Development Status

The solution identification effort provides for the non-recurring engineering efforts associated with future retrofit projects that increase Reliability, Availability, and Maintainability of the aircraft through the FYDP. As these projects are tested and qualified, they are implemented via the retrofit program.

ModificationTitle.val: Helmet Mounted Display and Cueing System (HMDCS)

Description.val:
The Helmet Mounted Display and Cueing System (HMDCS) program will fund the procurement and installation of Group A hardware 143 aircraft, Group B hardware for the cockpit, and pilot-worn Group C hardware (286 HMDCS). The Group A hardware will be integrated on block 30/35 F-22 aircraft.

The production will include one full HMDCS set for the trainers, and will begin in FY 2022.

Milestone/Development Status

Development is continuing, a request for proposal released in FY 2018.

The TACLink-16 program consists of software and hardware development necessary to field basic Link 16 Transmit capability on the Block 30/35 F-22 aircraft.  Link 16 Transmit will be accomplished via an Open System Architecture (OSA) integrated with F-22 legacy avionics.  TACLink 16 will begin fielding with Increment 3.2B installs in 3rd Quarter FY 2020 and continues through FY 2023.  This program includes Mission Support Requirements and other government costs to include, but not limited to, support equipment, long-lead sets, and initial spares.  Cost and schedule for the program is an estimate and will not be final until the program baseline is completed. Funds may be used to resolve emerging safety of flight and diminishing manufacturing sources issues, accommodate technology insertion and fulfill FAA or other
mandates necessary to ensure continued aircrew safety and mission effectiveness.

Milestone/Development Status

TACLink 16 development began in FY 2016 and continues fielding through FY 2023. PDR completed in November 2017.

FY 2018 Advance Procurement for TACLink 16 procures long lead materials associated with the production and deployment of the TacLink 16 program. The funds will procure specialized support equipment to include benches, racks, trays, processors as well as titanium to support the group A installation of Polyalphaolefin (PAO) manifolds. TackLink 16 installation is currently projected to begin in FY 2021 and will retrofit 143 aircraft.

This program includes F119 Engine modifications, depot labor, and the support equipment (SE) tooling required for F119 Engine upgrades to improve long-term engine sustainment. This program funds engine modifications for 186 aircraft and approximately 103 whole engine spares. Quantities reflect individual kit procurement and installation. Engine modifications are necessary to improve the safety, reliability, maintainability, sustainability, mission performance, and affordability of the F119 engine in order to achieve full life status of 8,650 Total Accumulated Cycles (TAC).  Funds may be used to resolve emerging safety of flight and diminishing manufacturing sources issues, accommodate technology insertion and fulfill FAA or other mandates necessary to ensure continued aircrew safety and mission effectiveness. Engine depot inductions and inspections are funded through this program including depot and SE tooling for F119 Engine Parts to support F119 Engine depot modifications. Engines enter into depot induction, are inspected and when new issues are discovered, corrections are developed via the engine Component Improvement Program (CIP), PE 0207268F, and are implemented via modifications. 

Induction inspections are based on TAC counts. The 2,300 TAC core inductions began in FY 2011 and continue through FY 2019; the 5th stage Integrally Bladed Rotor (IBR) is limited to 3,600 TAC depot induction started in CY 2014 and ended in CY 2018. The next phase of inductions will occur at 4,325 TACs, also known as half-life inspections. The 4,325 TAC inspections will refurbish the F119 Engine in order to achieve full life of 8,650 TACs. Inspections may generate maintenance and repair actions that require engine modifications. Kit installations are done either at the depot or by field teams depending on the complexity of the effort. F119 Engine Modifications includes Mission Support Requirement to include, but not be limited to, travel, computer costs, and other miscellaneous contract support.

Milestone/Development Status

Development accomplished via the Engine Component Improvement Program (CIP), PE 0207268F.

Name.val: Structure Retrofit Plan:INSTALL KITS Group A (Active)
Structure Retrofit Plan:INSTALL KITS Group A (Guard)

Description.val:
The Structures Retrofit Program (SRP) is designed to retrofit F-22 aircraft with the structural improvements required to reach full service life.  SRP I completed in FY2014 and brought the F-22's service life to 2,000 hours. The current program (SRP II) is designed to extend the entire fleet to 8,000 hours per aircraft. The number of aircraft in this exhibit (166) is not reflective of the total fleet due to SRP kits being installed while the last two lots of aircraft were in production. Additionally, kit buys and their corresponding installs will not always match by fiscal year due to schedule changes in depot work flow. Kit installation quantities and costs are shown for modifications performed at the depot level only. SRP II includes Mission Support Requirements.

Installations will be complete in FY 2020.

Milestone/Development Status

Development complete.

This effort modifies training devices to simulate existing and future F-22 operational capabilities and maintain concurrency with the aircraft configuration. The modifications enable 4-ship Mission Training Centers (MTC), Weapons and Tactics Trainers (WTT), and Maintenance Training Devices (MTD) to provide realistic training. Modifications also include reliability, availability, and maintainability improvements. The actual quantity of trainers being modified will be determined at the annual Pilot and Maintenance Training Working Group meetings chaired by ACC. There will be 45 Pilot Training Devices beginning in CY 2019 and 26 Maintenance Training Devices for a total of 71 trainers. Modifications are done by contractor field teams. 

Trainers Modernization includes mission support requirements for the F-22 program office to include, but not be limited to travel, computer costs, and other miscellaneous contract support.

Milestone/Development Status

Development conducted in conjunction with ongoing modernization activities and Ready Aircrew Program taskings.

This program, P-3A Mod F22027, Crypto Modernization, is a new start.
Funding for the Crypto Modernization procurement begins in FY 2019 and will upgrade and install KOV-20/KSR-60 cryptographic module firmware on the F-22 fleet. Kit installation will be completed by contract field teams beginning in FY 2019. 

Quantities include 5 kits per aircraft and the necessary modifications to the existing rotatable pool of spares in inventory.

Milestone/Development Status

Development of the KOV-20/KSR module is ongoing and will complete as part of Update 6 interoperability.

Name.val: F-22 Tactical Mandates Kits:EQUIPMENT Group B (Active)

Description.val:
This program, P-3A Mod F22030, Tactical Mandates, is a new start.
F-22 Tactical Mandates consists of software and hardware necessary to provide the mandated tactical capability for Mode 5 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) Transpond/Interrogate.  The program also provides an opportunity to incorporate other updates to Link 16 capabilities not incorporated under the TACLink 16 program.  The mandate for Mode 5 is required by the Joint Requirements Oversight Council (JROC).  F-22 Tactical Mandates will begin fielding in 2nd quarter FY 2022 and continue through to the 4th quarter FY 2024.  This program includes Mission Support Requirements and other government costs to include, but not limited to, support equipment and initial spares.  

The pre-Engineering & Manufacturing Development (EMD) contract was awarded on 19 May 2016.  Cost and schedule for the program is an estimate and will not be final until the program baseline is completed.

Funds may be used to resolve emerging safety of flight and diminishing manufacturing sources issues, accommodate technology insertion and fulfill FAA or other mandates necessary to ensure continued aircrew safety and mission effectiveness.

Milestone/Development Status

F-22 Tactical Mandates development began in FY 2015 and continues fielding through FY 2024.

Mid-Life Updates represents future procurement of hardware and software capability enhancements to include a radar upgrade. The program will include contracted work, direct lab, CTF execution and Mission Support. 

The program will procure 143 kits.

Milestone/Development Status

Development efforts to begin in FY 2021. Production costs represent a future estimate.

Sensor Enhancements provides improved sensor capabilities to Block 30/35 F-22 aircraft to maintain air dominance and preserve first shot, first kill capability. The Procurement funding includes 143 kits, installation and spares.

Milestone/Development Status

Development Efforts are under way on the Sensor Enhancements. Proposal preparation activities for the RDT&E and Preliminary Design Review (PDR) begin in FY 2019, with a planned Milestone B in FY 2020.

The F-22 Global Positioning System (GPS) Military Code (M-Code) program consists of the software and hardware development, test and fielding necessary to ensure the F-22's ability to maintain Precision, Navigation and Timing (PNT) capabilities in GPS degraded environments.  This effort will include the integration of Embedded GPS/Inertial Navigation System (INS) Modernization (EGI-M) onto the F-22 for M-code-associated GPS enhancements, as well as other capabilities, to prevent exploitation of the weapon system by adversaries and provide assured PNT.  Antennas and the EGI-M retrofit will be accomplished incrementally.  The M-code program procurement funding is for production of 183 antenna retrofit kits and 177 EGI-M retrofit kits.

Milestone/Development Status

Development is expected to begin in FY2018 and end in FY2023.

The pylon program will integrate, test and field a modified pylon assembly by retrofitting existing pylon assets and procuring fuel tank fairing kits to mate baseline fuel tanks to modified pylons. The modified pylons will provide increased range, loiter time, and survivability due to improved aerodynamics.

Milestone/Development Status

Development began in FY2016, under PE 0207128F.
